flowRoot.flowPara: Semi-stateless: scales linearly if an appropriate load balancing algorithm is used. Some state is cached, if a node goes down performance will drop but the data can be recalculated automatically.

Stateless: scales linearly by simply adding more nodes. If one goes down, we can fail over to another almost transparently (connections get cut off, but since HTTP has short-lived connections this should have little effect)
Sharded: scales linearly. Each node is responsible for a small subset of the data. If one goes down, that data is temporarily unavailable (or temporarily read-only, if shards are replicated)
Replicated: scales badly; there can be multiple read-only copies but only one writable master server. The complex inter-related data makes it hard to split into separate shards.
